text:
He stopped in his tracks, overwhelmed by despair and a heavy dose of cynicism. With a wave of his hand, he pushed on. “Just get it over with!”

Outside, the heat was unbearable. No rain for days. The streets were a mess—dust, bricks, and the stench from shops and bars. Drunk guys stumbled around, Finnish vendors shouted, and broken-down cabs rattled by. The sun blared in his eyes, making it hard to see, and he felt dizzy, like someone with a fever stepping into the harsh light.

As he approached the street, anxiety gripped him. He glanced at the house, then quickly looked away. “If they ask me anything, maybe I’ll just spill it,” he thought, getting closer to the police station.

It was about a quarter-mile away, newly moved to the fourth floor of a fresh building. He’d been to the old office ages ago. As he entered the gateway, he spotted a peasant climbing the stairs with a book. “Must be a house-porter. Guess the office is up there,” he thought, deciding to climb without asking anyone.

“I’ll just walk in, drop to my knees, and confess everything…” he imagined, reaching the fourth floor. The staircase was steep, narrow, and drenched in dirty water. The kitchens of the apartments opened onto the stairs, left wide open all day. It was a pretty grim scene.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist is overwhelmed by despair and trepidation as he approaches the police station, contemplating confession.
